ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Chamber music skills and listening to other groups

A lot of experience playing chamber music in a (constructively) critical and high-level setting. Lots of practice optimizing rehearsal time and learning how to polish a piece in a relatively constrained amount of time.

Chamber music class has allowed me to develop general collaboration and communication skills as well as skills specific to music such as performance, analytical listening, rehearsal techniques and more.
Learning to play chamber music, analyse works and work with coaches to make the most out of the music
I became better at working with others
I improved my skills in playing, listening to, and commenting on chamber music.
I learned new repertoire for my chamber arrangement

I definitely learned about communication with the members of my group and how other types of chamber groups approach their study of a piece. I learned how to give clear and detailed feedback on chamber performanceslistening critically!
I continued to develop my collaborative, interpretive, and rehearsal skills as a chamber musician.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths - weekly coaching, Sophiko is great, I think Callisto quartet is very knowledgeable and I would love them to give a class in the beginning on how to rehearse chamber music 
Weaknesses - repertoire could be expanded, would love to develop more chamber-music specific skills with Callisto beyond repertoire interpretation

The emphasis on having lots of coaching helps tremendously with developing the piece, however I feel that the classes on Tuesdays could be a little more efficiently run? Perhaps telling the students to pay attention to certain things in the performance that the performers would like to work on.

I appreciate the opportunity for students to give and receive feedback from each other during classes, as I think this is an important skill to have in the musical world that I haven't had as much opportunity to practice previously. I don't have any suggestions for major improvement in this course.
Strengths: Lots of attention from great TA's (the coaches), chance to perform in class once a month.
Coaches are very knowledgable

This course struggles with the question of who it is for: it is effectively a course for white and East Asian string players and pianists. Of course we all know that the classical music community has a problem with race and class, but this course does not do anything to counteract those stereotypes. All eight of the coaches for this course are white. There would be more interesting perspectives in the class if there were more wind players and coaches, and if wind groups were allowed to play more significant repertoire. Unfortunately the class time conflicts with Concert Band rehearsals and therefore this is not an option for many high-level musicians. Admissions for the course are quite political and arbitrary, left entirely to the personal whims of the few YSM-affiliated faculty members who teach undergraduates. But overall this is a pretty good course that students learn a lot from, even if most of that learning comes from working with fellow students rather than from the instructors.

Strengths: You learn a lot about musical collaboration and ensemble work. Low-stress workshop classes and great people. 
Weaknesses: Wish it was worth a full credit.
Time is wasted at the beginning of every semester by presenting about our pieces  everyone would rather spend the time rehearsing and having extra coachings.

I liked the studio class format which allowed us to critically evaluate our classmate's performances. Coachings were also always quite helpful for developing our interpretation of the music we were learning. I would appreciate more focus on teaching chamber music skills, such as how to rehearse, tuning chords, and cuing.

This is a great classI think it is very strong for people who want to have a structured chamber music environment at Yale. I think more wind players as coaches would be amazing :') and I wish groups could choose their own repertoire! Or at least have a little more input.. but otherwise I had a great experience.

I think that the assignment of giving presentations at the beginning of the semester worked well during COVID, but has now outlived its usefulness. Many of the presentations were effectively blow-by-blow musical summaries of the pieces with little attention to interpretive questions. More importantly, spending so much time on presentations at the beginning of the semester

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! I would also love to see a second section of this class created so that more interested and qualified students could play chamber music at Yale since it is such a great experience!
Yes, if you are looking to improve your chamber skills.
Yes! Anyone who plays an instrument should audition.
If you want to play chamber music then yes. If you're not committed to dedicating multiple hours a week to a half credit course, then no.
I would absolutely recommend this course to other students who are passionate about chamber music or motivated about chamber music enough to devote time to rehearsing and practicing.
Absolutely. A really great opportunity to play chamber music.
Great way to make friends and become better at my instrument

Yes, this can be a good course that you can learn a lot from. But you should try to talk to people who have taken the course before first to figure out if it's the right fit for you. Also, the admissions process is not entirely fair nor merit-based, and so you shouldn't feel bad if you aren't accepted. There are many opportunities to play great chamber music at Yale, and this is just one of them.

It is a lot of work for just half a credit, but the people and learning opportunities make it well worth your time. It requires a lot of communication and being on top of your part, but I found this easy since the repertoire and people were inspiring and encouraging. I had a great time getting to know my groupmates and rehearsals/coachings were always great. Wendy, Sophiko and the Callisto Quartet are incredibly skilled musicians and wonderful people in general. I highly encourage auditioning for all musicians.
This is a great course if you want to play chamber music at a high level as an undergrad. It is also a great way to get to know other serious musicians
I would! To any student who wants to play chamber music in an organized way, and to listen to others play.
Yes, this has been one of my favorite classes at Yale.
